mobs.long_desc: A lovely young pearl cockatiel hen is preening herself here.
mobs.desc: Nymphicus hollandicus (opaline) Though all of the birds within the aviary look to be rather well-off, this young hen is exceptional, her body being as long as your arm, her long tail adding again as much to her size.  Unlike the naturally-bred cockatiels, the pearl is not grey but rather is covered in lovely scalloped patterns of yellow, white, and light grey feathers.  Like her contemporaries, her cheeks glow a dusky orange, and the long, curling crest atop her head gives her face an incredible range of expression.  You can't imagine ever wanting to harm such a friendly and beautiful creature.

mobs.long_desc: A whiteface cockatiel regards you with deep interest.
mobs.desc: Nymphicus hollandus (charcoal) This fiesty young cockatiel looks to have been the product of human intervention rather than natural breeding, his face lacking the distinctive yellow mask and orange cheeks; instead, his body is a charcoal grey lighter than that of his wilder fellows and his face pure white.  Still present is the expressive crest atop his head and the long, graceful tailfeathers characteristic of his species. For some reason this young cock is regarding you with the oddest stare. Perhaps it's that time of the year, or maybe he's just mad because he missed lunch, but it looks like he's got an aggressive gleam to his eye.  Better watch out!

mobs.keywords: wild-quarrion quarrion cockatiel wild bird grey white
mobs.long_desc: A small grey-and-white bird perches on a dead limb before you.
mobs.desc: Nymphicus hollandus Though somewhat drab of body plumage, the wild cockatiel, or quarrion as it is known in its native lands, has a beautifully-colored face and an expressive crest atop its head that makes it one of the more interesting birds within the aviary.  Long in body and in tail, this young cockatiel is about as large as your forearm, with charcoal-grey wings and tailfeathers highlighted by two lateral white patches.  His head is lemon-yellow with brilliant orange cheeks, and atop his pate sits a curling crest that he can raise and spread forward or lay flat back against his head depending on his mood.  Don't let his relatively small size fool you, for his eight toes each are capped with sharp nails and his hooked beak is strong and sharp, and the quarrion is the fastest flier within the aviary.

mobs.long_desc: A small troll lurks in the shadows, given away only by his foul stench.
mobs.desc: What is such a foul beast as a troll doing inside the walls of such a beautiful place?  They very stench of his long-unwashed coat is enough to pollute the slender but swift brook flowing beneath the bridge, and it makes your stomach queasy to even contemplate struggling in melee with it, your hands caught in the matted snarls of fur caked with mud and grease.  Each breath from the beast carries the stench of carrion and offal.  Perhaps if you could force the troll into the clear, swift stream you might be victorious (or at least give it a good bath) - fortunately this one looks to be but a lesser specimen and not one of the man eaters seen in less civilized areas.

mobs.long_desc: A delicately-beautiful parrot has lighted on a branch nearby.
mobs.desc: Polytelis alexandrae Surely this beautiful young bird has flown through a liquid rainbow; his tail a light green reminiscent of spring grass, his undersides a pale mauve, his wings graduated from olive to lemon.  The underside of this parrot's chin glows pink, while atop his head the feathers grow in a cool baby blue.  Almost concealed by his wingtips, a patch of purple marks where his tail begins.  As he takes flight, a shrill "queet-queet" marks out an alarm.

mobs.long_desc: A rather large budgerigar has taken an interest in you.
mobs.desc: Melopsittacus undalatus Along with the quarrion or cockatiel, the budgerigar is one of the most widely-distributed birds within the aviary and also one of those most often tamed as pets.  The average budgie is rather small, but this one seems to be a most impressive animal, its body about twice the size of your fist.  Covered in lime-green plumage with grey wingtips, the budgerigar shares the cockatiel's lemon face but lacks the latter's orange cheeks and expressive crest, instead possessing a smooth crown striped with black.

mobs.long_desc: A spectacular red-plumed bird looks about to open its beak in song.
mobs.desc: Platycercus elegans The feathers of this beautiful bird are such a rich, deep red that it could easily be mistaken for a blossoming flower amongst the trees.  Adding to the rosella's beauty are blue stripes down the longer primaries and beneath the hookbill like a mask, while the bird's tail feathers are taken with a greenish tint.  The rosella's voice matches its beautiful appearance, varying in range from an alarmed "kweep-kweep" in flight to a gentle, warbling whistle while perched.

mobs.long_desc: A large white-and-pink cockatoo looks at you curiously.
mobs.desc: Cacatua leadbeteri The chest and head of this large cousin of the true parrots is a delicate but solid pink, while her wings and tailfeathers are a soft, pure white.  In flight you can see that the underwings are also pink, conjuring an image of strawberries and cream.  Like the smaller quarrions, the cockatoo possesses a crest atop her head, though not one quite as expressive as the cockatiel's. However, when extended her headfeathers are quite a sight, banded first white, then red, yellow, and red again before ending at the tips in white.

mobs.long_desc: A beautiful blue kingfisher dips his long beak at you in greeting.
mobs.desc: Tanysiptera galatea Though not a particularly large bird, the paradise kingfisher carries himself with regal bearing worthy of his status as an image upon the shields and breastplates of many a score of knights.  Two long, graceful feathers sweep out beyond his otherwise stumpy tail, a wondrous sight when the kingfisher takes to wing.  His back and wings are a deep royal blue as are most of his tailfeathers, while his underbelly and throat are pure white.  While perched, his tail flits up and down comically, and his voice sings out a trilling call.

mobs.keywords: little-bittern bittern little plump golden-brown bird
mobs.long_desc: A plump golden-brown bird stares at you from the reeds.
mobs.desc: Ixobrychus minutus It's little wonder this little bird's attitude tends to be rather bitter; his appearance gives plenty of reasons for ridicule, with a plump, almost- spherical body and short, stubby wings with no tail to speak of.  Long, spindly legs and a slender, reaching beak are his only protruding features, as even his neck seems to blend into his plump body.  Plumed with a yellow-gold throat and wings and a crown highlighted by black, the bittern blends well with the brown reeds amongst the swamps, perhaps an adaptation well-suited to conceal his comical little body from laughing eyes.

mobs.keywords: fairy-wren blue breasted fairy-sized wren bird
mobs.long_desc: A fairy-sized blue wren is perched on a branch nearby.
mobs.desc: Malurus pulcherrimus This splendid little bird's tail is cocked at a most ridiculous angle, the slate-blue feathers protruding at nearly a right-angle from the rest of the bird's body up into the air.  His crown and mantle are dark blue with an almost purple sheen to them, while his breast tends to a deep navy.  A v-shaped orange stripe adorns his back, followed by brown patches atop his wings and white underpants.

mobs.long_desc: A beautiful dove is eating at some pieces of fruit before you.
mobs.desc: Ptilinopus regina Similar in size and shape to a large pigeon, the superb fruit dove is superior to his ill-reputed cousin in almost every way.  Instead of dull grey or dirty white plumage, the fruit dove is rainbow-colored with green wings and back, orange feathers about his head like a hood, lime highlights circling his eyes and ears, and a brilliant purple crown.  Cinched about his belly is a black waistband giving his underplumage a tailored look.  The fruit dove as his name implies feed primarily on the fruits of the eucalyptus forests and nearby tropical rainforests.

mobs.keywords: zebra-finch finch zebra bird orange stripes
mobs.long_desc: A small bird with an orange beak and zebra stripes flits about your head.
mobs.desc: Poephila guttata The zebra finch gets his name from a series of fine black-and-white bars covering his throat and wider contrasting banding along his short tail feathers.  Though his wings and upper side are a somewhat drab grey-brown, his underside is soft white running to a mottled chestnut brown speckling beneath his wings.  Most spectacular is his head, a fine grey setting about orange eyes, beak, and two chestnut-orange cheek coverts.  As he lights atop a slender branch, his tail flicks about in a figure-eight pattern while he studies you with sharp eyes.

mobs.keywords: many-coloured-parrot hatchling many coloured parrot bird
mobs.long_desc: A beautiful hatchling parrot waddles toward you.
mobs.desc: Psephotus varius Even without her full adult plumage, this young many-coloured or Mulga parrot is a beautiful sight.  Plumed mostly about the body with drag olive feathers that will grow in emerald green at her first moult, her body is highlighted with orange about her vent area, yellow rump feathers, sky blue along her tail, and gold and blue patches on her primaries.  A yellow patch just above her cere and a dollup of orange on her crown makes up this young parrot's face.  Given six months or a year of growth, surely she will be the aviary's prime beauty.

mobs.keywords: southern-cassowary sick bird cassowary southern large
mobs.long_desc: A large cassowary sits here with its leg splinted.
mobs.desc: Casuarius casuarius Perhaps the aviary's largest fowl, the southern cassowary is a distant relative to both the emu and ostrich, sharing traits of both.  Like the emu, the cassowary's feathers are double-shafted, splitting about halfway down their length into two smaller feathers and are finely-filamented giving it a hairy appearance.  Two powerful legs give it a ground speed similar to that of the ostrich, and like that larger bird the cassowary lacks wings.  As if to prove the link to dinosaurs of old, the cassowary's head is crowned with a prominent bony casque or ridge, and a turkey-like wattle hangs from its neck.  Mostly black of body, the bird's neck is highlighted with blue and red. This particular bird must have injured itself either in some kind of territory dispute or another accident, as one leg has been splinted by the crack veterinary staff of the Ickle Aviary.  Hopefully in a few weeks the cassowary will be back to its old self, but for now it is a bit peeved at being cooped up in the infirmary.

mobs.long_desc: A man in dirty coveralls gives you an angry scowl.
mobs.desc: The man before you looks to be one of the grounds crew of the aviary, dressed in coveralls spotted with soil and green vegetation stains.  In one hand he hold a pair of nasty-looking garden shears, and on his face is a look of cold fury.  Even as you wonder what could have the man so stirred up, he mutters under his breath something about, "Those damn kids ... first killing janitors, then my comrades... I'll show them."  Apparently he is upset about the trend of murdering the Mielikki Topiary gardening staff. Before you can be about your way, you hear one last snippet of grumbling. "I should have been a postman," he whispers as he catches hold of your arm. "Then maybe they would understand."

mobs.long_desc: A huge kingfisher laughs in your face at your puniness!
mobs.desc: Dacelo novaguineae Very similar in appearance to the smaller kingfishers of the rainforest, this large bird looks like he thinks very little of you.  His massive bill, colored black atop and bone-yellow below, is certainly a sharp and lethally- effective weapon, and each of his six toes is tipped with a deadly claw.  His massive body is brown striped with black along his wings and back ranging to white on his belly and underpants.  Blue highlights checker his wings, and in flight his stubby tail is spread impressively wide.  Just looking at you is enough to produce the kookaburra's distinctive call, a raucous laughing that filled with disdain.

mobs.long_desc: A tall slender man, adorned in glimmering white mail stands here in radiant light.
mobs.desc: This tall being is adorned as one of the Frost Rangers of the North. However, he stands nearly 10 feet tall and looks to be a half-elf.  His mail shimmers in the light, and is white as the pure snow of the northern regions, with traces of ornate forest green linings.  This is the Avatar of the god Haddixx.

objects.ground: A beautiful marble fountain stands in the clearing here.

extras.text: This beautiful fountain appears to have been carved from a single block of marble, rather amazing as it stands about twice your height and three times that wide.  A series of basins carry water down the sides as they fill and overflow, the glistening liquid eventually running out a large sluice on the western side where the vast volume of water becomes a swift brook. All manner of the aviary's winged species wing about in the flowing water, splashing the life-giving fluid all about as they make fun of the simple task of bathing on this warm afternoon.  So many of the brilliantly-plumed creatures light upon the marble basins that the fountain looks more a floral arrangement than a sculpture.  Perhaps you wondered at first about the plainness of the white marble, but as a backdrop for the avians it makes a perfect picture. Carved into the side of the fountain nearest you is some kind of inscription, though you'd need to take a closer look to make out what the letters say.  Just below the inscription is a circular carving of a beautiful woman set bas-relief in the gleaming white stone.
For the bounty of nature: Shall you never forget the wonder of life Selinathalatretestra - 1998

The carving appears to be an image of the goddess Selina.  The sculpture is surprisingly intricate, detailed so much so that you wonder what master craftsman captured her beauty and essence so in such a simple medium. The scene rendered shows the goddess at home in her Waterfall Grotto. Seeing her home you can easily comprehend her love of all things of nature; it is of little wonder that she should touch the Aviary with her grace and grant the citizens of the bleak north a respite from winter's grasp within these walls.

The water spurts from the uppermost basin to first fill it and then flow down through a series of bowls, pools, and basins until it pours into a swift brook that moves off to the west.  The water is crystal-clear and refreshingly crisp to the touch, likely melted ice from beyond the walls of the aviary.  The liquid reminds you of your dry throat; surely the birds would not mind if you took a small drink from one of the sparkling basins.

objects.ground: A beautiful feathered crest has been left here.

extras.text: Long yellow and grey feathers make up this piece of stylish headwear.  Upon the pate of some hapless bird it must have been beautifully expressive, as the crest itself would swing up or lie back against the bird's head to express interest, excitement, fear, and love.  Holding the feathered garment in your hands, you cannot help but feel sorry for the bird and wonder if you might be able to recreate even a degree of its vitality.

objects.ground: A dry loaf of rye bread has been dropped here.

extras.text: Baked apparently from grains harvested within the aviary itself, this loaf of bread is coarse and rather crude, but certainly looks appetizing to the empty of stomach.  Breaking the dark brown loaf open, there are quite a few whole kernels and seeds of grain still intact, and the flour certainly was barely crushed and sifted.  Perhaps this bread was intended as more of a treat for the birds above than for human consumption.

objects.short: a nasty pair of garden shears
objects.ground: A nasty-looking pair of garden shears has been forgotten here.

extras.text: Though not exactly industrial-sized, these garden shears have a wickedly- sharp serrated edge to their blades and a handle that feels warm and heavy in your palm.  Certainly they could clip through the most stubborn of dragon- shaped shrubbery and perhaps even be turned to more gruesome ends - wouldn't those blades do a number on someone's arm or fingers, and wouldn't it be something to see the metal handles protruding from the back of yon adventurer?  Indeed, the shears make for a nasty weapon. There is an inscription of some sort along the handle.
Mielikki Topiary Gardenworks

objects.ground: A pile of feathers lies at your feet.

extras.text: This warm, large garment is tailored entirely from feathers.  Upon closer examination, the cloak looks to be made up of a long cape and two wings attached to the sides into which you could slip your arms.  Though somewhat restrictive of your movement, the wings give you a feeling of freedom, almost as if you could take to the skies and soar amongst the birds themselves.

objects.ground: The sharp beak of a hookbill lies on the ground here.

extras.text: The beak of a parrot, this grey hook-shaped bill has razor-sharp edges honed daily by its former owner.  Though most birds are not aggressive, only the most foolhardy would not look to its own defense.  It looks as if someone has drilled two holes in the sides of the beak and run a leather thong through them so that you could tie the hookbill onto your head; it might also function well as a kind of dagger in hand.

objects.ground: Someone has forgotten a small, speckled egg here.

extras.text: About as big around as your fist, the smooth off-white surface of this egg is speckled with tiny flecks of blue and yellow, giving it an almost marbled appearance.  The egg is warm in your hand, and you can almost feel the beating of a tiny heart inside it.  Perhaps if kept properly warm and cared for, in a few days the most wonderful of treasures might be discovered inside.

objects.ground: The grounds crew has neglected to clean up a bit of droppings here.

extras.text: Yech!  Though the birds within the aviary's walls are far from domesticated - much less housebroken - happening upon such a nasty bit of droppings is an unpleasant surprise; generally the aviary grounds crew seem to do a pretty good job keeping the paths clean, turning such offal into the soil to act as fertilizer for the exotic plant life. The core of the droppings is a greenish-grey snakelike solid, surrounded by an off-white liquid that is quickly drying in the sun.  Though bird droppings do not have the disgusting smell of other animal feces, they are still rather repulsive nonetheless.

objects.ground: A tasty spray of millet grows before you here.

extras.text: A slender brown stem supports a wide blossom of tiny seeds, giving the millet spray the appearance of a cat's tail even down to the fuzzy filaments growing all about the seeds much like tiny hairs.  Though perhaps the millet does not look all that appetizing to you, to birds it is a treat on par with ice cream and other unhealthy sweets.  Many a feathered flier can be seen about the aviary picking away at the tiny but tasty seeds well into the evening hours.

objects.ground: A pair of feather breeches has been discarded here.

extras.text: These fine pants are made of a light fabric to which are sewn hundreds of soft feathers.  The plumage looks to have come from all sorts of birds, with long blue and green feathers likely from parrots lined up beside the smaller browns, whites, and greys of birds like finches and budgerigars.  Though their value as armor might be questionable, the breeches do look to be rather warm and even comfortable - and a must-have for every dandy's wardrobe!

objects.ground: A long feather whose tip oozes blood is on the ground at your feet.

extras.text: Once a feather is completely grown and mature it is like human hair - dead and unfeeling.  However, as they grow in, a bird's feathers have their own blood supply and can indeed feel pain.  Occasionally something happens to cause a bird to break or otherwise lose one of these bloodfeathers. Other than the dark vein of red down its center and its broken, uneven end, this feather seems like any other.  Whatever bird lost it must have had spectacular yellow and blue plumage... but what good is it to you?

objects.ground: Someone has dropped a pair of downy sleeves here.

extras.text: Made of a thin, stretchy material lined with a warm layer of fuzzy down, these sleeves would be perfect for keeping your arms warm beneath your overcoat. However, the thin material would provide little benefit for warriors and might seem even a bit sissified for the more beastly of occupations.  The thin material has enough stretch to it that you might even be able to wear the sleeves about your legs like a pair of tights in a stretch (no pun intended! )

objects.ground: A beautiful jeweled cockatiel has been lost here!

extras.text: Someone had to have paid thousands of gold pieces for such a spectacular piece of artwork - yet this wondrous little figurine came from within an actual bird's egg!  Accurate down to the smallest detail, this heavy metal statuette of a cockatiel is encrusted with jewels of all sorts: dark brown faceted tourmaline stares back as the bird's eyes, small citrines and rubies create the distinctive orange cheek patches, and smoky quartz and clear diamonds make up the feathers.

objects.ground: A small feather bracelet lies forgotten here.

extras.text: Though simple in appearance, there is something more to this small bracelet than meets the eye.  Simply holding this band of woven feathers in your hand makes you feel stronger both of body and of mind.  Slipping it about your wrist you discover a small sparkling gemstone mounted amidst the feathers.

objects.ground: A deep blue feather is sitting here, getting dirty.

extras.text: This beautifully curving feather is a deep royal blue, just like the kingfisher it comes from.  It's a primary flight feather from the left wing, so it would probably make an excellent writing pen.

triggers.name: Aviar_troll_greet
triggers.commands: * Simple greet trig set percent %random.100% if %actor.vnum% == -1 if %actor.level% > 99 wait 1 msend %actor% %self.name% cringes in terror as you appear! else if %actor.level% < 100 wait 1 msend %actor% %self.name% sniffs at the air and wrinkles its nose.  Its stomach growls ominously. msend %actor% %self.name% whispers to you, 'Is you tasty good-eats?' if %percent% > 65 wait 1 mechoaround %actor% %self.name% roars in terrible hunger and lunges for %actor.name%!! msend %actor% %self.name% roars in terrible hunger and lunges for you! kill %actor.name% end end end else end

triggers.name: bittern_rand_attack
triggers.commands: * Random chance to attack! set rnd %random.char% if %rnd.vnum% == -1 if %rnd.level% < 100 wait 1 mechoaround %rnd% %self.name% flies into a rage! msend %rnd% %self.name% flies into a rage and attacks you! kill %rnd.name% end end

triggers.name: bittern_greet_attack
triggers.commands: * attack them players! if %actor.vnum% == -1 if %actor.level% < 100 wait 1 mechoaround %actor% %self.name% flies into a rage! msend %actor% %self.name% flies into a rage and attacks you! kill %actor.name% end end

triggers.name: angry-gardener_speech1
triggers.commands: say My friends... in the topiary.  Even took their scissors.

triggers.name: angry-gardener_speech2
triggers.commands: say I know it was them that did it... they took his scissors and left him for dead.

triggers.name: angry-gardener_speech
triggers.commands: wait 1 say Those bastards kill them all... grumble wait 1 say One day they'll all pay for what they did to my friends.

triggers.name: angry_gardener_death
triggers.commands: mecho %self.name% shouts, 'Noooooooo!   I WILL be avenged!  %actor.name%, you wretch!'

triggers.name: angry-gardener_fight
triggers.commands: snarl %actor.name% tell %actor.name% I will kill you.

triggers.name: angry-gardener_greet
triggers.commands: msend %actor% %self.name% peers at you intently. wait 1 msend %actor% %self.name% tells you, 'Was it you?  Did you kill my friends?'

triggers.name: angry-gardener_receive
triggers.commands: * * comment * if %object.vnum% == 18000 wait 1 scream wait 1 shout %actor.name% is a murderer!  I'm going to kill them. mload obj 46413 mat 46449 drop bracelet wait 1 kill %actor.name%

triggers.name: angry-gardener_rand1
triggers.commands: say Watch yourself, kiddo.  I've got my eye on you.

rooms.name: Sunny Path
rooms.description: You stand on a small path leading away from the arctic square of Ickle. The thin wintry air hangs still and quiet so that sounds from the farthest corners of the city carry through the atmosphere.  Above you a rare opening in the omnipresent gray cloudmass hanging over Ickle admits a strong shaft of sunlight that warms the cheery path if not in temperature then in spirit.  To the north the path takes an easterly bend as it meets a tall stone wall, while central Ickle and the arctic square lie behind you to the west.

North.description: The path continues to the north.

West.description: The arctic square of Ickle is behind you.

rooms.name: Sunny Path Bend
rooms.description: The paving stones of the small narrow path beneath your feet are but fringed with the cold featherings of ice and snow, admitting a welcome glimpse of color through the ubiquitous white of winter that coats everything this far north. Certainly the pale yellow beams of sunlight streaming through a break in the dense grey snowclouds above are partly responsible even if they do little to lift the pallor and chill of the air.  Immediately to the north a massive stone wall extends at least sixty feet into the air.  To the east the path continues to be illuminated by the thin sunbeams, while the bustling center of Ickle lies back to the south.

East.description: The path continues to the east.

South.description: The path begins immediately to the south.

rooms.name: Sunny Path
rooms.description: Perhaps it is the subtle warmth of the rare sunlight stealing through the cloud cover above, or maybe the passage of many feet that has beaten down and away the icy white carpet of ice and dense snow from the rich brown paving bricks of the path beneath your shoes.  Either, both, or neither, the change from the blinding blur of white is more than welcome even if the air itself retains the eternal chill of winter.  This cheerful little path extends into the east and the west.

East.description: The path continues to the east.

West.description: The path continues to the west.

rooms.name: Sunny Path
rooms.description: The sunlight breaking through the heavy, low stormclouds eternally dumping snow upon Ickle and the north makes walking along this path a pleasant stroll. The pale sunbeams do little to actually warm the air, but nevertheless make for a cheery atmosphere in the otherwise bland arctic clime.  To the east you can see gates set in the northern wall, while the path also continues to the west and back toward central Ickle.

East.description: The path continues to the east.

West.description: The path continues to the west.

rooms.name: Outside the Ickle Aviary
rooms.description: Two large brass gates break the towering northern wall.  The metal is covered with tiny beads of water that occasionally congregate and run down to the ground in thin rivulets, turning to ice in the bitter cold as they fall. Touching the gates, you can feel heat that seeps through your mittens and dispels the chill in your bones.  Something tells you that the air beyond the doors would be steamy and almost tropical, despite the frigid arctic all about you.  You could open the gates and proceed beyond, or you could follow the sunny path to the east, where it dead-ends, or to the west, back toward Ickle. There is a large sign affixed to the wall.

North.description: The gates look very sturdy, but you should be able to open them.

East.description: The sunny path continues to the east.

West.description: The sunny path continues to the west.

extras.text: Welcome to the Ickle Aviary Within these walls you shall find a brief refuge from the arctic cold so many of us call home, a glimpse of a land and environment far to the south. Beyond these immense portals you shall find nary a flake of snow nor crystal of ice.  Instead you will discover lush rain forests, thick wooded land, and waves upon a grassy sea. When the good lady Ariana Shelti was wooed to the north by her love she left behind those lands of the south, and though her love was warm soon the chill of this frosty realm did eat at her heart.  To ease the homesickness of her native land thus the good residents of Ickle did build this sanctuary and populate it with the colors of the birds of the south. The Aviary is more than merely a place to sight-see; indeed, industrious young adventurers might find glory and honor to be won, and perhaps the dark hearts of those more bent from light and happiness might feel some of the weight lifted from their burden.

The gates are made of thick, burnished brass that the weather and time have etched black in places.  Standing perhaps ten feet high and each hinged door just under half that wide, the gates must weigh tons.  From the moisture condensing on their surface and the warmth of the metal, the doors must contain an atmosphere more suited to the tropics than the arctic city of Ickle.

rooms.name: End of the Sunny Path
rooms.description: The sunny path comes to a dead-end here, framed by a towering marble wall to the north and the smaller walls of the city of Ickle to the east and south.  A small park bench stands against one wall, and were this a more temperate clime you could imagine spending a pleasant afternoon dozing on the weathered wooden bench.  Oddly enough, the wall to the east is covered with a curtain of withered brown creeper vines whose growth seems inexplicable in the eternal chill of arctic winter.  Behind you the sunny path extends to the west.

East.description: Vines cover the wall to the east.

West.description: The sunny path extends back to the west.

extras.text: Long, unending winter storms have bleached away the paint that once made this bench stand out against the cold white all around you.  The wooden planks are pitted and worn but stable enough to still give the weary traveler a brief reprieve from the wanderlust that wears his or her boots thin.

The cold chill of the arctic has made everything within sight an almost universal, blinding white.  Yet here are vines perhaps more suited to the southern environs, creepers whose tendrils have etched their way into the very stone of the wall.  Though they are brown, brittle, and withered, at one point surely they had some form of nourishment and warmth to have spread so completely over the eastern wall.

rooms.name: Secret Stair
rooms.description: This stair certainly was not meant for public usage; the door's carefully concealed mechanism and the curtain of withered vines were surely made to hide away this passage from curious passers-by.  Something warms the air here as well, the heat probably behind the growth of the vines on the other side of the wall.  The stairs wind upward into shadows, and the secret opening in the wall is directly behind you to the west.

West.description: The wall is broken by a fine line where a section can retract and permit passage out into the cold of Ickle.

rooms.name: Bend in the Wall Path
rooms.description: The path takes a bend around the corner of the walls here, continuing to the east and to the north as the tall outer walls of the aviary define the western and southern boundaries of the path.  A smaller inner wall whose corner stands to the northeast encloses a section of the aviary, likely keeping one small environ separate from the rest of the sanctuary.

North.description: The wall path continues to the north.

East.description: The wall path continues to the east.

rooms.name: Wall Path
rooms.description: The towering outer wall of the aviary stands to your south, its surface slick with water where the chill of the winter outside has seeped into the stone and pulled the moisture out of the humid, warm air filling the inside of the bird's home.  To the north is a smaller wall separating a small section from the rest of the enclosure.  Thus the path you stand upon is defined by the two walls to the north and the south so that it runs east-west here.

East.description: The wall path continues to the east.

West.description: The wall path continues to the west.

rooms.name: End of the Wall Path
rooms.description: A small wall to the north separates one section of the aviary off from the rest, apparently to keep its environment somewhat separate from the rest of the bird sanctuary.  The sounds of birds are everywhere, and as you look up you can see their colorful forms flitting through the trees and sky all around you. To the south is the thick, towering wall of the aviary itself, solid slabs of marble that keep out the sharp chill of the arctic air.

East.description: The entrance to the aviary lies immediately to the east.

West.description: The wall path continues to the west.

rooms.name: Entrance to the Ickle Aviary
rooms.description: The transition from the chill wintry air and thin sunbeams of the arctic lands about Ickle to this almost tropical paradise is so sharp that the change is like a physical slap - but not an unpleasant one, as shortly the humid, warm air gives you pause to shed your thick cold-weather coats, gloves, layers of garments.  Fortunately there are pegs and bins along the walls for storing any clothing you should choose to shed.  The warmth easily supports all manner of avian species, filling the branches of trees farther north than they could possibly live and darting across the sky as blurs of color startling after the solid whiteout of the northern lands.  Far above you can see a shimmering barrier between the aviary and the outside atmosphere, keeping in the summer heat and the birds themselves.  Paths branch out into the aviary proper to the east and west, while a third crosses a small stream on a footbridge to the north.  Ickle and the cold of the north lie through the gates to the south.

North.description: A small footbridge crosses a shallow stream to the north.

East.description: A path leads off into the aviary to the east.

South.description: A large set of gates is set into the southern wall of the aviary.

West.description: Walls to the north and south define the path to the west.

rooms.name: Southern Aviary Path
rooms.description: Birds fill the trees everywhere you look, all of them small bundles of bright red, yellow, blue, and green, nothing like the dull penguins so common this far north.  Rather they all seem to be from a much more tropical clime, most colored to stand out against the flowers and lush greenery of their native lands and attract loving mates from the crowds of other birds all around.  The path continues east-west, with the entrance to the aviary westward.  The south is blocked by the thick, towering walls that keep out the cold, while a stream flows across the ground the the north.

North.description: A shallow but brisk stream cuts a narrow channel through the ground.

East.description: The southern path continues to the east.

West.description: The aviary entrance lies just to the west.

rooms.name: Southern Aviary Path
rooms.description: Were it not for the towering stone monolith of the aviary wall to the south you could easily believe yourself transported half a world away from the chill arctic climate of Ickle and the north.  Birdsong is a continual accompaniment to your leisurely stroll, a melody composed of so many different voices were it not so beautiful it would be cacophony.  The soft gurgle of a brook to the north only adds to the natural song.  The path follows the wall to the east and west from where you stand.

North.description: A small stream gurgles across the aviary.

East.description: The path ends to the east.

West.description: The southern path continues to the west.

rooms.name: End of the Southern Path
rooms.description: The southern path ends here as tall yellow grasses erode the boundary of the trail, its end vanishing into a miniature savanna as this corner of the aviary seems to be devoted to the more arid species of fowl.  A few tall, lonely trees dot the grounds, their branches sparse and only marginally-leaved.  Here the birds seem less lively-colored, their drabness certainly a survival characteristic meant to hide them from hungry predators.  The grasslands continue to the east, while just north of you is a splendid fountain serving as a bath to what looks like half the world's birds.  The footpath emerges from the savanna to return to the west as well.

North.description: You see a fountain covered with hundreds of birds enjoying an afternoon bath.

East.description: The grasslands continue toward the wall of the aviary.

West.description: The southern path continues to the west.

rooms.name: Grassy Haugh
rooms.description: Tall grasses that reach in places as high as your waist cover the ground all around you, their stiff yellow-brown leaves indicative of their native arid land.  The air here, too, is drier than in the rest of the aviary, though the temperature is just as warm if not even hotter.  Few trees populate the nearby area, but those that do stand are kept company by flocks of small birds filling their sparse branches.  The outer wall of the aviary is immediately to the east, where the savanna ends abruptly, but the grasslands extend both to the north and west of where you stand.

North.description: The grasslands continue to the north.

West.description: There is the beginning of a path emerging from the tall grasses to the west.

rooms.name: Wall Path
rooms.description: The thick outer wall of the aviary stands impenetrable to the west, beads of moisture running down its height as the cool outer air chills the stone as it meets the humid atmosphere inside the sanctuary.  A smaller wall to the east serves to separate a section of the aviary off from the whole, isolating some small ecosystem from the rest.  The ground at its base looks slightly soggy and smells of decay; perhaps the wall is then some kind of dike holding back wetlands on the other side.  Not far to the south the inner wall takes a turn to the east, while to the north the trail continues between the tall stones.

North.description: The wall path continues to the north.

South.description: The wall path continues to the south.

rooms.name: Soggy Marsh
rooms.description: Thick, sucking black mud grips your boots with every step, threatening to steal your footwear or spill you face-first into the sour muck.  The smell of decay is stifling, and across the swampy flats you occasionaly see small will-o'-the-wisps flickering along the ground.  In places stagnant pools of water reflect the sun like polished black mirrors, and surely the tarry dark muds conceal any number of quicksands and other quagmires.  Walls to the west and south serve to contain the swamps, though to the north the grounds seem to dry as thicker brush and briars take over the land.  The marsh extends east as well.

North.description: There is a thick briar patch to the north.

East.description: The soupy lowlands extend to the east.

rooms.name: Soggy Marsh
rooms.description: The stream that flows under the bridge to the east backs up into the ground here, leaving the soil a soupy marish of sucking black mud and quicksand. Most of the grasses and small shrubbery that carpeted the landscape along the paths throughout the aviary have drowned here, their fibrous corpses slowly decaying into the slimy back muck, and the few trees that remain are little more than hollowed-out shells.  Yet some of the birds do seem to prefer the dank swamps to the lush forests and grasslands.  The swamps continue to the west, where you can see a short retaining wall that looks to keep check over the spread of the muddy quagmire.  To the north, away from the continual influx of stream water, the ground dries and gives way to prickly brushes and weeds, and to the east is a small bridge crossing the brook.

North.description: The north is covered in thick briars and other small brush.

East.description: A small arched footbridge crosses the brook to the east.

West.description: The fens continue to the west.

rooms.name: Arched Footbridge
rooms.description: The path crosses a shallow brook beneath your feet upon an arched stone footbridge.  Whatever stonemason crafted the bridge possessed the highest degree of skill, shaping each paving stone so that the gentle curve of the path up and over the waters is as smooth as possible, and the small lips on the sides of the footbridge are fitted so keenly the seams are barely visible.  To the east is the gurgling brook itself, and the west holds a soggy fen.  The path continues north-south on both sides of the bridge; it looks as if you could also descend to the creek itself.

North.description: The path continues to the north.

East.description: There is a small stream to the east.

South.description: The path continues toward the entrance in the south.

West.description: You can see a smelly swamp to the west.

rooms.name: Shallow Brook
rooms.description: Though the water around you is not very deep, it is cold and fast-flowing, necessitating a boat of some sort to make safe passage through the brook.  The flow of the stream is from the east, and behind you to the west it disappears beneath a low, arched footbridge.  Off in the distance to the east you can see a fountain virtually covered with birds enjoying the cool water beneath the sun, while paths wind through the aviary to the north and the south.

North.description: A path winds through the aviary to the north.

East.description: The stream continues to the east.

South.description: A path winds through the aviary to the south.

West.description: The stream passes under a small bridge to the west.

rooms.name: Shallow Brook
rooms.description: The water that whips through the narrow stream around you is clear and chilly, likely melted from the ice all around the city.  Luckily your boat is sturdy enough to resist the rapid flow of the creek, as even though the waters are shallow they are quite swift.  Directly to the east you can see the source of the brook, a large fountain that is almost covered with birds cavorting in the warm sun.  Paths lie to the north and the south, while the stream's waters flow into the distance to the west.

North.description: A path winds through the aviary to the north.

East.description: There is a large fountain to the east.

South.description: A path winds through the aviary to the south.

West.description: The brook continues to the west, where you can see a small bridge in the distance.

rooms.name: Fountain Clearing
rooms.description: The grassy haughs standing to the east and the forests just to the north thin into a wide clearing here around a large marble fountain.  A vast volume of water erupts from its center to flow down one side and into a shallow stream running off to the west, and hundreds of birds dart in from all over the aviary for a brief bath or afternoon swim, quickly dispersing at your approach. Paths wind through the aviary to both the north and the south, while tall grasses fill the land to the east.  If you had a boat, you might be able to follow the brook as it flows away from the fountain as well.

North.description: A path winds through the aviary to the north.

East.description: Tall grasses give the land to the east the appearance of a savanna.

South.description: A path winds through the aviary to the south.

West.description: The bubbling, quick-flowing stream flows out to the west.

Down.description: It looks like there is a hatch leading down at the base of the fountain.

extras.text: The hatch appears to have been carved so as to appear part of the paving stones at your feet, blending almost perfectly into the ground.  In fact, you were rather lucky to find it at all, and it takes a few minutes of study to discover the mechanism that opens it.

rooms.name: Grassy Haugh
rooms.description: The thick, tall yellow grasses of the southern outback stretch to the distant outer walls of the aviary to the north and south, while the eastern wall is a closer at hand.  Despite the sound of flowing water nearby to the west, where you can make out a fountain, the air here is rather dry and hot, duplicating the arid clime of the southern savannas.  The few trees are filled with small, drab-colored birds that take wing at your approach.

North.description: The grasslands continue to the north.

South.description: The grasslands continue to the south.

West.description: You can see a fountain covered with happy birds bathing in its waters.

rooms.name: Wall Path
rooms.description: Two walls isolate this path from the wide-open areas of the aviary, one the thick, towering outer wall that keeps out the arctic chill to the west, the other a smaller wall that looks to be some kind of dike or retaining wall keeping some small section of the aviary separate from the rest of the ecosystem.  Water beads on the massive outer wall as its surface is cooled by the air beyond it.  Directly to the north is a bend in the path as the smaller inner wall reaches a corner and turns to the east and the thick outer wall also swings to the right; the south hold more of the same walled path.

North.description: There is a bend in the wall path to the north.

South.description: The wall path continues to the south.

rooms.name: Briar Patch
rooms.description: The thick sucking mud of the fen to the south serves as poor soil for most plants, but here as it begins to dry all sorts of small scrub have made their home.  Thick, prickly briar bushes, their stems woody and tough unlike the softer greenbriar of the forest, tug at your clothes and skin, and various burrs and ticks attach themselves to you as you brush past their "flowers.  " With so much of the ground given to the dense, woody foliage, the briar patch is a favored home for many species of birds.  A small retaining wall to the north and west serves to contain the spread of the underbrush, while the thicket continues to the east.

East.description: The thicket continues to the east.

South.description: A smelly swamp lies south of the briar patch.

rooms.name: Briar Patch
rooms.description: Dense undergrowth of briars, mimosas, and scrubby eucalyptus trees tugs at your clothing and makes progress through this patch of the aviary very difficult.  The ground beneath your feet is crumbly and black, the dried edge of the marish whose scent of decay assaults your nostrils from the south.  A low wall to the north prevents further spread of the thick growth, but the briar patch seems a favorite home to many of the birds in the aviary, almost a ready-made nest.  A trail cuts through the middle of the aviary to the east, while the briars extend west.

East.description: A trail cuts through the middle of the aviary.

South.description: A smelly swamp lies south of the briar patch.

West.description: The thicket continues to the west.

rooms.name: Aviary Footpath
rooms.description: This path winds through the center of the Ickle Aviary, giving its travelers the most splendid view of the bird sanctuary.  Far above is a shimmering barrier that traps the heat and keeps the birds from straying into the fatal cold of the arctic.  Off to the east you can see a stream and distant grasslands, while to the west stand a stinking fen and dense clots of briars. To the northeast is a heavily forested area, and as the trail winds further to the north you see the beginnings of jungle foliage.  Far to the south lies the entrance to the aviary.

North.description: The path continues toward what looks to be a jungle or rainforest...

East.description: A small path winds toward grasslands and a forest.

South.description: The path crosses a bridge that leads to the aviary entrance.

West.description: Dense briars fill a thicket to the west.

rooms.name: Northern Aviary Path
rooms.description: This path tours the northern segment of the aviary, passing through a thick eucalyptus forest that dominates the northern horizon and into a lush savanna grassland to the east.  Directly to the south you can see a swift little brook, while to step north would place you within the forest proper.  Though the grasslands to the east seem far away, the footpath continues in that direction for some ways.  Directly behind you is another path that cuts through the middle of the aviary, leading north-south.  Above you birds dart from tree to tree, rarely dropping to your level to gather seeds or other food from the ground.

North.description: A thickly-wooded glen leaves the aviary to the north in shadows.

East.description: The path continues to the east.

South.description: A swift brook flows to the south.

West.description: A north-south path running through the middle of the aviary is west.

rooms.name: Northern Aviary Path
rooms.description: Well-walked brown paving stones mark this trail as it runs east-west through the northern section of the aviary.  Trees line the path to the north, and in particular a large eucalyptus stands towering above the rest of the wood and is frequented by many colorful birds.  The grasslands that are almost within reach, standing just to the east along the trail.  A small stream fills a narrow channel directly to the south, impassable without a boat, though to the southeast you can see a fountain that is likely the source of the waters.

North.description: There is an impressive eucalyptus tree to the north.

East.description: The path continues to the east, where enters the rolling savanna.

South.description: A stream makes rapid progress across the aviary to the south.

West.description: The path continues to the west.

rooms.name: End of the Northern Path
rooms.description: The northern path comes to an end as it vanishes into the tall yellow grasses of a savanna to the east.  Nearby to the north a thick, shadowy forest composed mainly of eucalyptus trees stretches across the horizon.  Though numerous birds flit between both environs, the sound of birdsong intensifies to the south, where in the distance you can see a large marble fountain.  Behind you the path returns toward the center of the aviary in the west.

North.description: A dense eucalyptus forest is to the north.

East.description: A rolling savanna is to the east.

South.description: You can see a fountain covered in birds taking an afternoon bath.

West.description: The path continues to the west.

rooms.name: Grassy Haugh
rooms.description: The tall grasses of the southern savannas stand as high as your knees and waist across much of the land here, their leaves made stiff and yellowed by days in the dry heat native to their arid clime.  When a small breeze does cross the plains, the grasses dip and bend in waves that roll across the land. Very few trees are in sight, most of them skeletal shapes nearly devoid of branches and leaves.  To the north and east the outer wall of the aviary shuts out the cold, while the grassy haugh continues to the south.  Just to the west you can see the beginnings of a path that runs back toward the center of the aviary.

South.description: The grassy haugh continues to the south.

West.description: You can see the beginnings of a path leading back to the center of the aviary.

rooms.name: Bend in the Wall Path
rooms.description: The thick outer wall of the aviary to the west takes a bend to the right just ahead of you, causing the wall path to take a turn to the east.  The outer corner of the small retaining wall that has formed the other side of this path can be seen to the southeast, itself also making a right-hand turn.  The air that wafts from the east is hot and steamy, the moisture it carries being deposited against the cool outer wall to run down the sides.  The walled path extends to the south and the east.

East.description: The wall path continues to the east.

South.description: The wall path continues to the south.

rooms.name: Wall Path
rooms.description: The towering outer wall of the aviary defines the northern boundary of this path, while a shorter wall to the south serves to close off some portion of the aviary from the rest.  The air around you grows increasingly humid and warm as you walk further east, so much so that water condensing onto the cooler outer wall drips down almost continually to the damp paving stones beneath your feet. You can follow the path east-west here between the walls, with the middle of the aviary lying somewhere to the east.

East.description: The wall path continues to the east.

West.description: The wall path continues to the west.

rooms.name: End of the Wall Path
rooms.description: The aviary's thick outer wall takes a bend to the north here, opening up a large segment of the aviary that looks to be populated by rain forest, certainly an explanation for the intense humidity present hereabouts.  The smaller retaining wall to the south comes to an end shortly to the east as well, bringing an end to this walled path.  Another, wider footpath to the east looks to run north-south through the center of the aviary.

North.description: You see a dense, almost tropical rain forest.

East.description: A wide footpath running north-south is just to the east.

West.description: The wall path continues to the west.

rooms.name: Aviary Footpath
rooms.description: The wide paving stones of this footpath stretch almost from one end of the aviary to the other, the entrance lying in the distance to the south.  In the opposite direction to the north you can hear many birds in song amongst the thick greenery of a miniature rain forest.  Low banks of steamy fog obscure the loins of the larger foliage, a product of the hot, humid air filling this section of the aviary.  Off to the east you can see a less tropical forest made up of tall eucalyptus trees, while to the west the path is enclosed by walls.

North.description: There is a small clearing in the rain forest to the north.

East.description: You can see a thick forest to the east.

South.description: The path continues to the south.

West.description: A walled path extends to the west.

rooms.name: Wooded Glen
rooms.description: Tall trees make up a forest more reminiscent of the land around the town of Mielikki beyond Nikozia to the south.  Hundreds of eucalyptuses ranging from small shrubbery to towering grandfathers of the woods fill almost every inch of the ground beneath their leafy canopies.  Sunlight comes in small yellow splotches through the shade, making the air light and pleasant.  The forest extends to the east, where one particularly impressive tree towers above the rest of the woods, while to the north the forest give way to a more tropical wood.  Both to the south and the west paths wind through the aviary.

North.description: A rain forest is to the north.

East.description: There is an exceptionally large tree in the east.

South.description: A path winds through the aviary to the south.

West.description: A path winds through the middle of the aviary to the west.

rooms.name: The Base of a Large Eucalyptus Tree
rooms.description: Though many of the trees throughout the forest are impressive in both their height and girth, none compare to the massive eucalyptus that stands in the center of this clearing.  All around the other trees have withdrawn, almost as if in respect, and a ring of sunlight falls just beyond the reach of the tree's branches.  The forest continues to the north, east, and west, though it thins as a path traverses the aviary to the south.  From all directions you can see and hear birds of all sorts, but there is one song that stands out above the rest that comes from somewhere high in the branches above you.

North.description: The forest continues to the north.

East.description: The forest continues to the east.

South.description: A path winds through the aviary to the south.

West.description: The forest continues to the west.

Up.description: It appears that you might be able to climb up through the branches.

extras.text: The large tree before you towers above the others of the forest, its limbs nearly tickling the shimmering magical boundary high above that keeps out the chill arctic sky.  Only the touch of the gods - or likely that of the goddess Selina - could create such a magnificent creature.  Indeed, a creature, as the life force flowing from the tree is more than that of a mere plant. Birdsong fills the woods around you, a symphony only such creatures could manage, but there is one voice that stands out above the rest, a solo amongst the magnificent chorus.  Squinting up into the branches in search of the lovely creature who must create this song, you can see only what might be a large nest nestled in some of the uppermost branches. Though most of the branches spread over the sky far above you, there seem to be enough placed about the lower portions of the trunk to support a climb should you choose to investigate the upper extremities of the eucalyptus.

rooms.name: Wooded Glen
rooms.description: Though the afternoon sun in Ickle pales in comparison to even the setting rays of the sun in more southern climes, inside the aviary it streams down in powerful yellow beams that warm the air and the soul.  The branches of the forest all about you provide shade most graciously as they cast gay shadows about the soft soil of the forest floor.  As you stare around the beautiful woods, you can see that they extend both to the north and to the west, with a particularly impressive eucalyptus towering over the rest of the forest to the west.  A path to the south approaches low, rolling grasslands, and in the distance that way you can just make out the outline of a large fountain.

North.description: The forest continues to the north.

South.description: A path winds through the aviary to the south.

West.description: You can see an immense eucalyptus tree to the west.

rooms.name: Thick Rain Forest
rooms.description: A steamy haze clings low to the ground, circling the lower trunks of thick jungle eucalyptuses and obscuring the soft loam beneath your feet.  Large- leafed vegetation fills the forest from the ground up into the sky where the misty moisture obscures the sun with a halo.  Even inside the aviary there is weather, as you can make out heavy banks of cloud cover above the uppermost branches of the trees.  The forest extends to the north and east, while the outer wall of the aviary creates a boundary to the west.  In the distance to the south you can make out the top of a low retaining wall just across a footpath.

North.description: The rain forest continues to the north.

East.description: A beautiful rainbow opens over a clearing in the forest to the east.

South.description: A path winds through the aviary to the south.

rooms.name: Rainbow Clearing
rooms.description: Hot tropical sunbeams stream down through an opening in the jungle canopy, making the humid, heavy air even hotter.  Staring upward through the clearing, you can see a beautiful rainbow that arcs across the sky where the thick mists refract the intense sunlight.  Beyond this small clearing to the north, east, and west lie more acres of the dense tropical forest, while to the south is a path that leads back through the center of the aviary toward Ickle itself. Flocks of colorful birds on the wing accompany the splendor of the colored arc, painting a picture no human hand could recreate against the soft blue backdrop of the sky.

North.description: The rain forest continues into the north.

East.description: The rain forest continues into the east.

South.description: A path winds through the aviary to the south.

West.description: The rain forest continues into the west.

extras.text: Rainbows are actually not arcs at all but rather full circles that light the sky with the illumination of the sun on a misty day.  Looking up at the small portion of this rainbow that is visible from the ground you are reminded of nursery school and names like Roy G. Biv, of mixing colors of paint and wondering how yellow and blue made green.  Yet with light the combinations are different, the primaries being red, green, and blue, their hues blurring between the stripes of the rainbow to create the many colors visible as water bends light.

rooms.name: Thick Rain Forest
rooms.description: The leaves of the plants winding all through every available inch of open space in the forest are much larger than you have ever seen before, many of the dark green appendages at least three hand-spans across and perhaps twice that long.  Thick, hairy vines wind about the trunks of every tree in sight, and scattered all throughout the greenery are all manner of flowers brilliant in their colors, many of the blossoms larger than your clenched fists.  The thick, vibrant jungle extends to the north and west, while to the east and south the air thins and dries slightly, giving way to a more temperate wood.

North.description: The rain forest continues to the north.

East.description: A towering forest of eucalyptus lies to the east.

South.description: A towering forest of eucalyptus lies to the south.

West.description: The rain forest continues to the west.

rooms.name: Wooded Glen
rooms.description: Such a thickly-wooded forest seems more than a bit out of place this far north of the tree line, but certainly the temperate clime within the thick aviary walls is responsible for the lush flora spread over so much of the grounds tucked out of reach of the icy fingers of the arctic north.  Among the towering eucalyptus trees flit all sorts of birds, their colors ranging from drab browns and greys to garish reds, yellows, and oranges, all species so far removed from the waddling penguins that they seem almost alien in comparison. The forest extends to the east and the south; in the latter direction there is one particularly tall tree reaching above the rest.  Walking to the west reveals increasingly-humid air as the forest dissolves into a tropical jungle.

East.description: The forest continues to the east.

South.description: You see an exceptional eucalyptus towering above the rest of the wood.

West.description: The woods dissolve into a tropical rainforest to the west.

rooms.name: Wooded Glen
rooms.description: Trunks as wide about as your full arm span fill the forest to the outer walls of the aviary to the north and east, towering eucalyptus trees whose roots would never penetrate the permafrost of the icy earth this far north without the helping hand of magic.  The upper boughs play host to a symphony of avian voices, the gaily-painted creatures more brilliant than a horde of flowers amongst the leafy green forest canvas.  The woods continue to the west and the south, where you can hear the efforts of countless other birds as they celebrate the joy of life itself.

South.description: The forest continues to the south.

West.description: The forest continues to the west.

rooms.name: Thick Rain Forest
rooms.description: The humidity of the tropical atmosphere in this corner of the Ickle aviary shrouds the ground with a thick mist and coats the sturdy outer walls of the aviary with a sheen of moisture that beads and continually rolls down to moisten the already-soaked ground.  The foliage that thrives upon the heat and ever-present dampness is mostly slender, roughly-barked trees and hairy vines whose rubbery leaves are often wider than your head.  The voices of the birds favoring this tropical clime at times seem almost human as they parrot the songs of strollers happily spending an afternoon away from the bland ice of the north.  The rain forest extends into the distance both to the east and to the south from where you stand.

East.description: The rain forest continues to the east.

South.description: The rain forest continues to the south.

rooms.name: Thick Rain Forest
rooms.description: Vegetation chokes every cubic inch of the rain forest around you, rendering the hot, humid air all about you a uniform green as vines as thick about as your arms and leaves larger than your two stretched palms.  Twisting trunks covered in thick, rough bark fill the space that the vines and lesser vegetation do not, and the dense mist and heavy humidity only increase the feeling of congestion and claustrophobia.  The thick jungle flora extends to the east and west, while the rain forest opens onto a clearing just to the south.

East.description: The rain forest continues to the east.

South.description: The rain forest opens onto a clearing just to the south.

West.description: The rain forest continues to the west.

rooms.name: Thick Rain Forest
rooms.description: Almost-human voices fill the branches as spectacularly-plumed parrots and other tropical birds light upon the boughs of the twisting, narrow tropical eucalyptus trees and raise their hearts in wondrous song.  The colorful avians mix with the blossoms of so many flowers to create a beautiful three dimensional living sculpture.  Though the outer walls of the aviary serve as borders to the north and east, the rain forest extends as far as you can see to the south and west, though visibility is problematic with so dense a growth of tropical flora.

South.description: The rain forest continues to the south.

West.description: The rain forest continues to the west.

rooms.name: The Branches of a Eucalyptus Tree
rooms.description: Mother Nature must have had you in mind when she encouraged this towering eucalyptus to reach her arms for the sky, placing sturdy branches exactly where you reach for them as you climb the wide trunk.  Somewhere above your head you can see a nest tucked among the branches.  From the same direction comes the most wonderful birdsong, a voice that would put many professional performers to shame with its timbre and clear pitch.  Beneath you is the forest floor, and all about you you can see the birds of the aviary going about their work and play.

Up.description: There is a nest tucked in the branches of the tree above you.

Down.description: The forest floor is just beneath you.

rooms.name: Inside the Nest
rooms.description: Woven through the upper branches of this magnificent eucalyptus are all manner of twigs, sticks, and long, grassy reeds, forming a kind of bowl nestled near the top of the tree.  Just above your head the uppermost branches spread out in a canopy that shades out the sun, leaving the inside of the nest cool and lit by splotchy beams of pale yellow.  Near the center of the nest a kind of bed is made up of soft down feathers, likely for the insulation of young birds and unhatched eggs.  Though you cannot climb further up the tree, you could ease yourself over the edge of the nest and travel down the trunk.

Down.description: The trunk of the tree extends down toward the ground.

rooms.name: The Observation Balcony
rooms.description: This small balcony overlooks the southern reaches of the Ickle Aviary, providing a magnificent view of the flocks of feathered beauties as they wing across the habitat.  From here you can see rolling plains of grassland to the east and muggy swamps to the west, but what catches your eye the most is a large marble fountain just off to the northeast.  Hundreds of birds of all sorts cover the sculptured fountain, frolicking in the cool water as it bubbles from the ground and spills from a series of basins to run off to the west.  It does not appear that this balcony was meant for public use but rather for private entertainment and viewing.  A couple of well-made chairs stand near the edge, turned slightly toward each other.  The balcony continues to the west, while a small staircase extends back down to the ground level from here.

West.description: The balcony continues to the west.

Down.description: Stairs lead down out of this balcony.

rooms.name: The Observation Balcony
rooms.description: Set into the outer wall of the aviary, this small observation balcony would be difficult to see from within the aviary itself, but it provides a splendid view of the birds and their habitat below.  In the distance to the north the edge of a lush forest is visible, and beyond it the hazy grey of the far-off northern wall of the aviary.  From this height many of the flights that pass by are at the same level as you stand, providing wonderful shows of color as flocks of birds pass by.  The balcony continues to the east.  There is a small telescope mounted on the railing here.

East.description: The balcony continues to the east.

extras.text: Though the telescope is nothing near what it would take to spy out the details of the moon or the heavens above, it does have the look of craftmanship about it.  The main tube is long and worked of a seamless cylinder of matte black metal ringed with gold at the ends.  A small dial acts as a vernier of sorts to focus the optics, and the pivot the scope stands attached to moves smoothly and noiselessly.  Peering through the lens you can make out all manner of birds throughout the aviary, all oblivious to your spying.  In particular, the large marble fountain to the northeast offers the most stunning views of the birds as they frolic in the cool waters.  Looking closely, you see a large bird looking back at you: .-; / /  ___, | | .'.---' ;  : / ._\ '| ./     -. /     .-. \:_ /     ( * )`; \ |  **  ^-^ <__ | / ****     \_,\| |  **      (   ' /            \

rooms.name: Beneath the Fountain
rooms.description: The rumble of moving water reverberates about this small chamber beneath the large marble fountain.  Along the ceiling run a series pipes, some barely larger around than your finger, others at least a half a foot wide.  Beads of water run along the outside of many of the pipes, eventually dripping to the floor and leaving this room rather damp and cold.  The passageway continues to the west where it seems much better-lit.  Certainly this is not somewhere that you should be; it would be prudent to climb back up through the hatch to the aviary above and forget that you ever were here.

West.description: The passageway to the west is well-lit and drier than where you stand.

Up.description: There is a hatch set into the ceiling leading back into the aviary.

extras.text: The hatch is slightly rusted from the continual moisture assaulting it from both sides but seems to be holding up quite well, all things considered. Though it is rather massive, made of solid metal on this side and encrusted with a slab of marble on the other, whatever mechanism operates it allows it to swing open and shut with hardly any effort.

rooms.name: Beneath the Bridge
rooms.description: Your mother used to scare you with stories of evil trolls and other nasty monsters that lurked in the shadows beneath bridges, but surely you have long since outgrown such foolery and childishness.  After all, there isn't really anything more than shadows and a few damp cobwebs under this bridge, and surely your mother's warnings were meant more as entertainment and possibly a bit of discouragement from happening upon a snake or other fairly benign creature. After all, there's really no such thing as a troll, is there?  The stream emerges into sunlight to the east, though travel along the waterway would surely necessitate a boat of some sort.  To the west the waters come to an end, vanishing into a ground soaked to swampland with their passage.  You could also climb back up onto the bridge above you.

East.description: The stream flows in from the east.

West.description: The stream vanishes into a swamp to the west.

Up.description: You should be able to climb up onto the bridge above.

rooms.name: A Granary
rooms.description: The air is thick with the musty scent of aging grain and seed as you make your way into this storage closet.  Large bins line each of the walls, each of them labeled with a different sort of seed: alfalfa, linseed, millet, rapeseed, sunflower, and countless others.  Standing on a shelf above the bins are a series of glass dishes that upon closer examination contain damp towels filled with tiny sprouts.  Perhaps these seeds are a supplementary food source for the birds above.  At any rate, the only exit is back to the south.

rooms.name: Nursery
rooms.description: This room must serve as a nursery for young chicks that are not quite ready to live on their own in the aviary above.  A series of small cages lines the north wall, their insides filled with soft, warm down.  The west wall features a long table, beneath which are assorted bins filled with large- mouthed syringes for feeding and numerous medical instruments.  A scale atop the counter must be to ensure young birds are growing at the proper rate.  A door set into the south wall leaves behind the nursery, while to the east you see a series of heated glass cages along the walls.

East.description: You can see a series of incubators lining the walls.

South.description: There is a door set into the south wall.

rooms.name: Incubator
rooms.description: Glass cages line the east and south walls before you, and peering inside one you can see a soft down bed and a small clutch of speckled eggs.  The air at this end of the room is hot and rather stuffy, surely a product of whatever keeps these small incubators warm.  On the counter against the north wall you see a device consisting of a paper screen, a candle, and an oval-shaped bracket - a confusing instrument until you realize it is used to illuminate the developing chicks inside unhatched eggs to check on their growth.  There are very few eggs in the incubators, but occasionally an egg is abandoned and must be cared for here.  The only exit is to the west, into the nursery where the occupants of these eggs should shortly be housed.

West.description: The nursery lies behind you to the west.

rooms.name: Boiler Room
rooms.description: Steel pipes stretch from the floor to the ceiling and fill most of the space at the end of this passageway, and a tremendous barrel-shaped boiler sits at the very heart of the maze of plumbing.  Occasionally one of the pipes will shake and shudder as if about to explode, and steam jets continually from the riveted joints.  This must be where the aviary's heat and humidity is created and maintained from the heat of the core of the world itself.  The only exit is back the way you came, to the east.  A large pipe vanishes into the ground beneath you.

East.description: A passageway extends beneath the aviary to the east.

extras.text: Laying your hand tentatively against the pipe that is about as thick about as your waist, you are startled to discover it cool, nearly cold to the touch. Beads of water condense from the steam all along its surface, and you can feel the gurgle of water passing through the pipe down into the earth.  A similar pipe emerges from the earth behind the boiler, out of reach, surely filled with steam scaldingly heated by the furious earth far below.

rooms.name: Stuffy Tunnel
rooms.description: From the west wafts a stifling wind of hot, moist air that makes this narrow passageway rather stuffy and uncomfortable.  From that direction you can hear hissing and an occasional rumbling that shakes you to your teeth.  Looking again to the west, you recall the saying about what curiosity did to the cat and have to wonder if it would be better to return to the east - after all, you really shouldn't be here anyway, in the maintenance tunnels beneath the aviary.

East.description: A maintenance tunnel runs beneath the aviary.

West.description: You can see a network of pipes, likely the source of the steam and heat.

rooms.name: Under the Aviary
rooms.description: Like the Pet Shop Back Room, you should NOT be here; these passages and rooms are devoted to the maintenance of the Ickle Aviary, not to the jaunt of some young and daring adventurer.  Storage closets lie to the north and to the south, containing materials you certainly shouldn't be messing with, while the passage itself extends to the east and to the west.  Best you make your way back up into the aviary proper before someone catches you.

North.description: The closet to the north appears to be filled with grain and seed.

East.description: The passageway extends to the east.

South.description: A groundskeeper's closet lies to the south.

West.description: The passageway extends to the west.

rooms.name: Under the Aviary
rooms.description: You can't help but feel ill at ease as you trespass through these maintenance tunnels beneath the Ickle Aviary.  Though they seem deserted at the moment, surely any number of workers might arrive about their business at any time.  Rooms to the north and to the south are closed off from this tunnel with doors, probably for good reason and not just to keep away curious eyes such as your own.  Though the tunnel extends to the west, perhaps it would be better to head east and back up into the aviary itself before you get into trouble.

North.description: A door is set into the northern wall.

East.description: The passageway extends to the east.

South.description: A door is set into the southern wall.

West.description: The passageway extends to the west.

rooms.name: Under the Aviary
rooms.description: This narrow tunnel leads east-west beneath the grounds of the aviary, certainly a maintenance passage for those charged with the upkeep of the aviary and its birds - definitely not you!  However, the aviary must be fairly self-sufficient as the passage seems deserted and the only sounds that reach your ears are the gentle drips of water to the east and an occasional rumble far off to the west.

East.description: The fountain stands just above the chamber to the east.

West.description: The passageway extends to the west.

rooms.name: Groundskeeper's Closet
rooms.description: The walls of this small storage closet are covered with all manner of groundskeeping tools from small shrubbery shears to large-handled shovels appropriate for planting fair-sized trees.  A couple of sacks of enriched potting soil lean against one wall, and above them the smaller spades and rakes suited to gardening work amongst delicate wildflowers.  Many of the tools do not look to have been recently used, a testament to the splendid way the flora of the aviary has taken to root even in this arctic waste.  The only exit leads north.

North.description: A maintenance tunnel beneath the aviary lies to the north.

rooms.name: Clinic
rooms.description: Occasionally a bird in the aviary takes a chill or otherwise becomes a bit unwell; when Polly develops the sniffles, she is brought here for expert treatment by the aviary's veterinary staff.  A couple of diagnostic tables occupy the west wall, while on shelves above and below them scales, stethoscopes, and other diagnostic tools sit in bins ready for use.  Along the south wall are a handful of observation cages where sick birds may spend the night or a couple of days getting better before being released back into the "wilds" of the aviary itself.  A door set in the north wall separates the clinic from the maintenance area, maintaining cleanliness and isolation for particularly ill animals.  To the east the clinic continues into a small but well-equipped surgery.

North.description: There is a door set into the north wall.

East.description: A small but well-equipped surgery is to the east.

rooms.name: Surgery
rooms.description: Sometimes a stay in the clinic is not enough for a particularly ill bird and more drastic measures are called for; here the experienced veterinarians of the Ickle Aviary can operate on an injured or dying bird in the hopes of saving its life.  Two steel operating stages are set up, one along the north wall and another to the south, while cabinets against the east wall contain bottles of alcohol, ether, iodine, and various medications.  Shelves hold razor-sharp scalpels and bins of sponges, hemostats, and other tools of surgery.  The clinic lies back to the west, the only exit from this room.

West.description: The clinic itself lies to the west.
